thread.title: MARKET SNAPSHOT: U.S. Stocks Eye Fourth Straight Weekly Gain
thread.title_full: MARKET SNAPSHOT: U.S. Stocks Eye Fourth Straight Weekly Gain

author: morningstar.com
title: MARKET SNAPSHOT: U.S. Stocks Eye Fourth Straight Weekly Gain
text:
By Anora Mahmudova and Barbara Kollmeyer, MarketWatch
Amazon, Microsoft and Alphabet soar after earnings
U.S. stocks pulled back from early-morning highs Friday but were still firmly in positive territory, extending gains from Thursday's big gains.
Investors are cheering a surprise interest-rate cut from the People's Bank of China's, which decided to take down its one-year deposit rate by 25 basis points to 1.5% and lower its one-year lending rate by 25 basis points to 4.35%.
China's central bank that came on the heels of a promise of more easing measures from European Central Bank President Mario Draghi (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/ecbs-draghi-opens-door-for-more-qe-in-december-2015-10-22)just a day earlier.
A rally in major technology stocks fueled by bumper earnings from heavyweight tech companies, Alphabet Inc., Microsoft Corp. and Amazon.com, were buoying the main indexes.
Michael Arone, chief investment strategist for State Street Global Advisors' U.S. Intermediary Business, said "it is encouraging to see solid earnings results from tech, consumer discretionary and health-care companies," looking beyond the easy-money moves by the ECB and China.
The S&P 500 advanced 16 points, or 0.8%, to 2,069, turning positive for the year as it erased most of the losses that sent it to correction territory in late August. On Friday, six of its 10 main sectors were trading higher. The technology sector surged 2.8% while health-care stocks rallied 1.2%, helping the broader index.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped 101 points, or 0.6%, to 17,590. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite outperformed other indexes, advancing 92 points, or 1.9%, to 5,013, lifted by the tech run-up. (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/the-best-six-months-for-stocks-is-about-to-begin-2015-10-23)
Read: The best six months for stocks is about to begin (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/the-best-six-months-for-stocks-is-about-to-begin-2015-10-23)
The central-bank action and earnings lured investors into riskier assets such as equities, sending European markets sharply higher. Meanwhile, government bonds sold off. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note rose 5 basis points to 2.08%, implying some rotation from bonds to stocks.
Thursday's relief rally for Wall Street retraced about half the "panic attack" since China devalued the yuan, said Ed Yardeni, chief investment strategist at Yardeni Research, in a note.
With central banks in the spotlight, more attention will now turn to the Federal Open Market Committee meeting Oct. 27-28, and the Bank of Japan's monetary policy meeting on Oct. 30.
Upbeat tech: Shares of Amazon(AMZN) jumped 6.9% after the e-commerce giant announced a surprise profit for the third quarter (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/amazon-posts-surprise-profit-while-sales-surge-2015-10-22-16485258) and forecast an operating profit for the holiday quarter.
Alphabet (GOOGL), formerly known as Google, announced its first-ever stock buyback plan (http://blogs.marketwatch.com/thetell/2015/10/22/live-blog-google-to-report-first-earnings-as-alphabet/). It will spend more than $5 billion buying back shares. Shares rallied 7.9%.
Read: Are tech rebels Amazon and Alphabet finally growing up? (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/are-tech-rebels-amazon-and-alphabet-finally-growing-up-2015-10-22)
(http://www.marketwatch.com/story/are-tech-rebels-amazon-and-alphabet-finally-growing-up-2015-10-22)Microsoft(MSFT) reported better-than-expected profit and revenue (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/microsoft-profit-buoyed-by-lower-costs-2015-10-22) late Thursday, and shares surged more than 10% Friday.
Also in the news Friday, Twitter Inc.'s(TWTR) chief executive officer Jack Dorsey, said he would give nearly $200 million of his own shares (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/twitters-jack-dorsey-gives-workers-nearly-200-million-of-his-own-shares-2015-10-23) -- or 1% of the company -- to the employee stock pool. Twitter shares rose 4.3%.
Other markets: The extra boost from China rate cuts added to already strong gains for the Stoxx Europe 600 index (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/european-stocks-on-pace-to-third-straight-weekly-gain-2015-10-23), posted its third straight weekly gain, finishing 2% higher as the market coasted on the potential for more stimulus from the ECB. A flash reading of October manufacturing activity in the eurozone (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/eurozone-pmi-gains-suggests-no-china-impact-yet-2015-10-23) came in higher than expected.
Closing ahead of that PBOC move, Asian markets (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/nikkei-hang-seng-climb-on-hopes-for-more-stimulus-in-europe-2015-10-23) also saw sharp gains across the board, with the Shanghai Composite Index rising 1.2%. The Nikkei 225 index closed up 2.1% as the Japanese yen continued to weaken against the U.S. dollar (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/euro-extends-losses-investors-turn-to-next-weeks-fomc-meeting-2015-10-23).
The euro also remained on a weaker footing against the U.S. currency.
Gold prices reversed earlier gains and fell 0.3% to $1,162.6 an ounce, while crude oil (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/oil-prices-rise-but-stronger-dollar-lurks-in-the-background-2015-10-23) dropped 1.4% to $44.75 a barrel.
 23, 2015 12:47 ET (16:47
